Coram, Roger wrote:
> We recently ran into an issue crawling a site protected by the software 
> Bad Behaviour <http://www.bad-behavior.ioerror.us/>. It seems that 
> though Heritrix by default identifies itself with Mozilla-compatible 
> user-agent it fails to send the �Accept� HTTP header which is apparently 
> passed by Mozilla browsers.
> 
> We had considered changing the user-agent to something more specifically 
> related to our organisation but we wanted to check whether anyone had 
> any thoughts on this or had run into any issues after amending the 
> user-agent.

For any significant crawling, I highly recommend customizing the 
User-Agent with an organization-specific string. It's typically more 
important to webmasters that the operators of the crawl and their 
purpose/contact-info be clearly identified, moreso than the software 
name/version. (Also, since some inattentive or aggressive crawl 
operators are especially likely to crawl with exactly the default 
string, some sites have already blocked that string.)

It is also worthwhile to ensure the page at the URL provided in the 
User-Agent includes multiple prompt contact mechanisms and some 
explanation of your crawling purposes that webmasters will appreciate. 
(Note that the "From:" header is usually not logged by target sites -- 
and so in H2/H3 setting "From:" is optional.)

Finally, if certain "Accept:" or other headers are required or preferred 
for your crawl, they can be set on the FetchHTTP component -- either for 
all requests, or just requests targeted at certain URLs (via the 
'overlays' mechanism). Even though the setting is called 
'acceptHeaders', in fact any HTTP header name->value you want added to 
requests may be configured there.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
